 A week ago I would have also said that I think Bush wins but the people I talk with all seem to be supportive of Kerry. Many are becoming critical of his new ad (over 60% in a CNN pole) which includes pictures from 9/11 which I can sort of understand but it still surprises me. Maybe it is just Kerry riding high after his most recent victories but if not I think Bush may be in a very tough battle for re-election.
syklopps61

I don't want to be one of those that is panicky because of what the polls show at this time. Afterall, recent history has shown that incumbents are behind around this time (Dole was ahead of Clinton for example) but have for the most part still won re-election. And, Bush has been busy running a country and hasn't known who is opponent will be until recently, so he hasn't been "fighting back". Let's face it, using the logic of people that believe these polls, the U.S. lost WWII on December 8, 1941. It is my belief however that Conservatives have character and Liberals don't. I haven't researched this, but it's probably a safe bet that these Third party candidates do more damage to Republicans than Democrats. Conservatives are more likely to cut their noses off to spite their faces-casting a vote of conscience even if it IS a "wasted" vote. I believe that if Hitler had a (D) next to his name, Liberals would vote for him because they just want their guy to win, no matter who it may be (think about it, fiscally, Bush is more Liberal than a Liberal but that (R) gets in the way). So, the "hate Bush" crowd will be out in force, blindly believing once again that it just can't be any worse than it is now. Obviously, it will be 2000 all over again, very close. Don't be surprised if the Democrats once again come up with voting "problems".
syklopps61

Oh, and about this ad by Bush, I think people need to get a life. I saw it for the first time this morning and was shocked that anyone could find anything offensive about that ONE image (of a U.S flag with remnants of the WTC behind). The Democrats remind me of a 4 year old that can call other kids names but when they have it thrown back, they cry that it's not fair. Kerry and the Democrats have politicized all sorts of things, but when THEY say it they claim it is their job to point things out. If Bush DARES to defend himself and offer another side or points out flat out lies, then the Democrats whine.
Nallyo

As long as people actually listen to what the candidates say, I think that Bush will do well. The thing is, he sticks with what he says unlike Kerry whose plan it seems is confuse the heck out of the voter by changing his vote to whatever best serves him politically. I believe that Kerry was also found to be the most liberal member of Congress, even surpassing Ted Kennedy.

If Kerry wins, you might better get out your life jackets...the ship will begin listing heavily to the left and subject to sink at any time. :xbanghead

If Kerry wins, you might better get out your life jackets...the ship will begin listing heavily to the left and subject to sink at any time. :xbanghead

 
 I wouldn't expect that Kerry would run the country into the ground or anything. Actually it generally democrats in the White House when the country pulls itself out of economic hardships. That isn't to say that it is a direct cause of democrats that this occurs but it is something to consider. But anyways the long and short of it is that Bush and Kerry will both do some good things and some bad things for the country. I doubt either will be so bad that we need to 'get out our life jackets'. Kerry is to questionable in his decision making for my tastes so I really don't have a whole lot of trust in what he says. He is a true politician. Bush is more of an average person or at least he portrays himself that way very well. I trust him more for not being a politician in all aspects of his presidency and that will go a long way when I have to decide who I am voting for. Maybe he will do a better job than Kerry, maybe he won't, but I trust him to do what he says he will do.

 Although recessions have started during the administrations of both parties, recently it\'s been the other way around. The recession we\'re just now coming out of started on Slick Willy\'s watch.
 
 As parties change over the years, so do their economic policies. Tax-and-Spend will lead to recession every time.
 
 Granted, Bush is spending a heap of money now, but some of the spending has become necessary because of the war on terrorism...a war that WE DID NOT START! We are wise to respond with extreme force and try every means possible to defeat the enemy.
 
 One could easily speculate on what might have happened to this nation if Al Gore had won the election. I contend that we would be infinitely worse off...as we will be if Kerry wins. If Kerry had had his way, we wouldn\'t even have the high-tech weapons that we\'ve already used to surgically destroy targets in Irag...and if Al Gore had won, we\'d never have used them.

 There are 4 versions of Bill Number H.R.3162 for the 107th Congress
 1 . Uniting and Strengthening America by Providing Appropriate Tools Required to Intercept and Obstruct Terrorism (USA PATRIOT ACT) Act of 2001 (Received in Senate from House)[H.R.3162.RDS]
 2 . Uniting and Strengthening America by Providing Appropriate Tools Required to Intercept and Obstruct Terrorism (USA PATRIOT ACT) Act of 2001 (Engrossed as Agreed to or Passed by House)[H.R.3162.EH]
 3 . Uniting and Strengthening America by Providing Appropriate Tools Required to Intercept and Obstruct Terrorism (USA PATRIOT ACT) Act of 2001 (Introduced in House)[H.R.3162.IH]
 4 . Uniting and Strengthening America by Providing Appropriate Tools Required to Intercept and Obstruct Terrorism (USA PATRIOT ACT) Act of 2001 (Enrolled as Agreed to or Passed by Both House and Senate) [H.R.3162.ENR]

 I apologize, I am not sure what your point is. I agree that they all have names that sound great to everyone. However, like I said, I am sorry, but I don't understand your point. If you could clarify, I would appreciate it. Thanks.

 No need to apologize. I was not clear. However, you alluded to my point...the titles of these four voluminous bills all include "to intercept and obstruct terrorism".
 
 A person must be suspected of terrorism before falling into the powers of these bills. Evidence must be shown to substantiate the suspicions prior to implementation of the powers within the bills.
 
 It is highly improbable that a law-abiding patriotic citizen will ever become suspected of terrorism.
jitobear

Patriotic citizens have nothing to fear from the Patriot Act.
 
 A person must be suspected of terrorism before falling into the powers of these bills. Evidence must be shown to substantiate the suspicions prior to implementation of the powers within the bills.
 
 It is highly improbable that a law-abiding patriotic citizen will ever become suspected of terrorism.
 
 This is very foolish and naive, plus you are wrong. 
 
 To be named an illegal combantant all that is required is a signed affidavit from a Pentagon employee who DOES NOT HAVE TO PROVIDE RATIONALE.
 
 The FBI can now search the history, financial records , etc of any US citizen without a warrant.
 
 The TSA can search you and your vehicle at airports without cause. They can seperate your from your children in the process and protest can (and has) led to arrest.
 
 I know someone who runs a web server that hosts Vigan sites, he is tapped and has had the CIA harass about his server being un-American because it is anti-farmer.
 
 Bottom line is that practically unlimited power has been granted government. This is far more dangerous to us than terrorism. The founding fathers knew this, that is why they made three branches, why there are checks and balances in place.
 
 Quite frankly the Patriot undermines this, as well ignores the Constitution and the Bill of Rights. I find it abhorrant. It is the reason I want Bush out. It is unforgivable to me that my president did not protect the Constitution.
